title: Rebuilding modules fails for dependents of `gdbm`
body:
### Summary

Rebuilding lmod module tree fails for dependents of `gdbm` (but succeeds for `gdbm`, and most other packages).

### Expected Result

`spack module refresh -m lmod --delete-tree -y` regenerates all Lmod modules

### Actual Result

Any module that depends on `gdbm` (e.g., `autoconf`) will throw a warning:

```console
==> Warning: Could not write module file [/Users/oxberry1/spack/share/spack/lmod/darwin-sierra-x86_64/Core/autoconf/2.69.lua]
==> Warning:    --> Cannot create a consistent method resolution
order (MRO) for bases Spec, SpecBuildInterface <--
```

### Steps to reproduce the issue

```console
$ spack install autoconf
$ spack module refresh -m lmod --delete-tree -y
...
```

### Information on your system

This includes:

 1. macOS / OS X 10.12.6
 2. I don't have any customizations related to autoconf, but would be happy to provide config files on request if they might be useful.

### History

I think this issue is a continuation of #6089 and #5864. Moving use of `spack_cc` into `setup_environment` solved issues relating to the expansion of `spack_cc`, so now instead of `gdbm` and its dependents throwing errors, only dependents of `gdbm` throw errors. The problem seemed to be introduced by #5893, and #7225 improved the situation slightly -- efore #7225, module files for `gdbm` could not be regenerated either.

### Narrowing down the problem

I tried running `spack -D module refresh -m lmod --delete-tree -y` and got as far as tracking down the error to within a method call at `spack/tengine.py:85`. Set a breakpoint at `spack/cmd/module.py:317` conditional on `'automake' in x.spec.name`. Once this breakpoint triggers, set a breakpoint in `spack/tengine.py:85`. Around the 15th-ish execution of that line (after the breakpoint in `module.py`), the method resolution order error throws. I couldn't narrow down the problem further.

### Workaround

A workaround for now is to reinstall the packages that throw warnings, because the module file written upon installation is apparently fine.
